reviews.review_text: It doesn't take you long to be pulled into the story. The Darkness 2 does a great job of immersing you into the feelings and thoughts of the main character, which is a rarity in modern day gaming. Often you are very disconected from the story and the emotions of the characters. Lately, the only other game I have played that did such a great job of pulling you in, emotionally, was BioShock Infinite.  Beyond the story, which while nothing especially impressive, what is there is enough and is well orcestrated. The most impressive feat is the game's ability to put you in the shoes of the main character and really doubt what is real and what is not real (in the game).  The gameplay is top notch though and if you enjoy shooters where you run from one area to the next and have to clear all the waves of enemies, then this is a game for you. The gunplay is fun and has impact and the tentacles are well implemented so that they are not overpowered and yet are still very fun and exciting to use. Ok, so I was expecting a regular FPS. But, I was wrong, Darkness II was a bit of a shocker to me, it was really good, kinda short maybe, but fun and had a solid story.  Story: (Trying not to make spoilers) The game is based on a comic series called, yep, you guessed it, The Darkness. You play as Jackie Estacado, a mafia boss that possess the forces of darkness.  Jackie tries to keep his darkness at bay, but after a rival mafia tries to kill you, you have no option but to start a war and unleash the darkness within you upon your enemies. But, when you unleash the darkness, you also cut a deal with it, and there's a price to pay at the end...  Graphics: The game graphics reminded me Borderlands but more realistic, and i like it :) kinda gives you the feel of a comics (which it is based on a comic series)  Gameplay: The game is FPS and RPG of some sort, where you gain XP from kills and level your skills, but apart from the guns and black magic you also have 2 tenticals that devours, kill, cutting off heads and ripping the limbs of people (Tons of blood and gore) When you are not cutting and killing, you also play as your little lackey, which is more stealthy than just killing everybody. Also, there are some levels that are purely for the story, they are short but very fun and delivers the awesome story to you, I loved those parts!  Conclusion: This game kinda surprised me, I loved the story, the cut-scenes are great, the gameplay is fun, the graphics are very nice and feel you get is very good. and even though it's short (took me about 6 hours to finish the game on Hard, but you can play it and make different decisions), it's really good! Play it!  ***There's also multiplayer but I didn't play it honestly, for no reason really***

The Darkness 2 has passable gameplay with about 10 weapons, half of them being what I would consider upgrades of a lower tier. It has a low replay value with not much to do after beating the Story and Vendetta/Hit List Missions (about 9-10 hours altogether). The best thing it has going for it and why I recommend the game is the single player Campaign portion of the game.  There is very little stalling in the plot. The game starts with the reveal of a new enemy and has about 3 objectives that are logical to progressing before starting the arc with the big bad guy. To me that is very efficient at getting to the point. I was nervous every time a sentimental moment happened, worried if the game would do a cheap jumpscare. It compelled me to care about what was going on and that is a rare feeling for me to have with dramatic stories like this.  Each time you can go back to your base, the other characters have different things to tell you that aren't always related to what you are doing, such as the story told about eddie when Jackie and Vincent are catching up. If you are into playing a game and exploring the subtle changes, you will be rewarded for your time. The plot constantly attempts to mess with your judgement of the situation and makes every chance for a choice an uneased gut check.  Check the game out when you have the opportunity to pay attention to the dialogue and really grasp the story. It was inspired by a comic book series and plays like reading an interactive graphic novel.

Fret not if you've never played the original Darkness. While many allusions are made its way, The Darkness II has you covered with a concise recap.  The first Darkness was a mess of a game, marred with terrible voice acting, animations, controls, gameplay, and numerous other bugs. The Darkness II, a product by another team of developers, is fortunately an exemplary sequel, fixing nearly every flaw and adding major improvements in ways unimaginable.  Graphically, The Darkness II's cel shading is simply beautiful, fitting right in with its comic book counterpart. The animations are smooth and the over-the-top violence is a blast to watch. Controls, especially during combat, flow extremely well, even in the face of the overwhelming number abilities available.  While the single player campaign isn't too lengthy, the game doubles its duration with the inclusion of a cooperative mode offering 18 missions and 4 new, unique characters. There's simply a lot of content to be found.  Grade: B

NOTE: Despite my short playing time, I have in fact completed this game. I also own a copy on Xbox 360, and this is the copy I completed.   The Darkness II is a phsycological horror first-person shooter sequel to The Darkness, a console only game released back in 2009. The original game was interesting despite its flaws, and was a highly enjoyable game in terms of story and gameplay. Its sequel, The Darkness II, goes above and beyond to deliver an absolute gem of a gaming experience, and a masterpiece of the art form.  You play as Jackie Estacado, the head of a feared crime family, who is the host to an ancient evil known as The Darkness - this evil resides inside Jackie and gives him supernatural powers. Jackie constantly wrestles for control, and The Darkness forced him to stand by and watch as his girlfriend, Jenny, was murdered.  Jenny's murder is the driving force of this entire game. Throughout the game, Jackie experiences hallucinations of Jenny, and interacts with her as she if she never died. These moments are the soul of the game; Jackie and Jenny are beautifully acted, and you can genuinely feel the emotion in these scenes. This made the story a compelling and enjoyable one, and I felt personally compellled to stick this game through to the end. In between cutscenes and interaction with Jenny and other NPC's, Jackie will engage in numerous combat situations. This game uses a unique and innovative combat system, in that the player is able to 'quad-wield'; the player is able to dual wield one handed firearms in combination with the demon tendrils produced by The Darkness. These tendrils let you rip, slash, throw, tear and stab your enemies in a variety of highly entertaining ways, but be warned that these kills are extremely gory and not for the faint hearted. In fact, the entire game is extremely dark, and contains very dark subject matter beyond the usual video game. The player also has to avoid street lights and other artificial lights and shoot them out where possible, as you cannot regenerate health or use Darkness abilities whilst in the light. This game is beautiful in every aspect. The game engine employs a distinct comic-book inspired aesthetic like the Borderlands games, and it really helps make the game look and run nice at the higher settings. Substantial effort and polish has gone into the production of this game, and it really shows; character models look and move realistically, and environments are dazzling to look at. In addition to the perfected single player campaign (which I have been careful not to spoil) there is a mini co-op campaign, which allows you to play with 3 friends and use a wide range of guns and abilities to kill enemies. This mode emphasises fun and action, and lacks the depth of the single player campaign. However, it was certainly fun, and I didn't feel like it detracted from the campaign in any way. Overall, The Darkness II is a masterpiece of the gaming industry. A brilliant, well constructed tale of love and loss and eventually redemption, this is a game for the ages. I can't recommend it any more than I already have, which is why this game earns a 10 / 10.

The game also features simple rpg mechanic that gives you the chance to upgrade skills depeneding on your play style, the game rewards you for killing in varied and unique was and its great fun to try out all the new tactics that you will unlock as you progress further along in a skill branch.  Only CON I can say with this game is the length, if you power your way through as I did on a second playthrough with some skills under your belt you can EZLY beat the game in about 4 hours, however if you take the time to test out new skills (BLACK HOLE FTW!!!), take time to talk to all the characters in the game, which I suggest you do on first run, the game can EZLY last for a good 8 hours. The Darkness 2 is, as the name implies, pretty ♥♥♥♥ing dark.  You play as Jackie Estacado, a mobster whose special skills have allowed him to rise to the very top of the New York underworld. And by 'special skills,' I am of course referring to the ancient demonic entity that lives within his body.  But when a bunch of cultists show up and try to steal the power away from him (because if an ordinary guy can use it to become king of the Mafia, imagine what someone with actual ambition could do with it), Jackie must use his eldritch abilities, and a veritable ♥♥♥♥load of increasingly large guns, to defend himself and prevent the power from falling into the wrong hands.  I'll be honest, I was surprised by how much I liked this game. I picked it up expecting a standard shooter with a vaguely gothic design aesthetic. What I wasn't expecting was a genuinely inventive and unique game with solid gameplay and some smart ideas bubbling under the surface. There are some very creative moments throughout the campaign, first as Jackie explores some strange locations, and then later when the demonic presence starts to drive him insane. The ending also qualifies for the 'Holy ♥♥♥♥ing Christ' award of totally unexpected story turns.  The gameplay is the standard gory shooter, but with the twist of dark and brutal abilities. You also get health by eating hearts that you tear out of dead bodies, which means the only way to get your way out of a tight spot is to use progressively riskier tactics to kill enemies and regain the upper hand. i3-4150, EVGA 750ti Superclocked ITX system.  Resolution: 1920x1080 Graphics settings: Max/Ultra Average framerate: 60 fps with vsync. Never noticed a single drop.  Input device used for game: Mouse and keyboard - tried my Xbox gamepad as well and it has full support!  *Spoiler alerts*  Let me begin with this: this game is definitely not your average shooter. The Darkness II plays and feels almost like the controls found in the Bioshock series, but with a neat twist...You can use both demon-tentacle-head melee attacks and dual-wield pistols simultaneously. I honestly haven't had this much fun since classic Shadow Warrior and Rise of the Triad. It has a pretty unique visual style that borders between actual comic book and cel animation. Digital Extreme's in-house Evolution Engine is extremely well optimized and the use of light (and darkness) and shadows are second to none. To be honest, I was not impressed by Jackie Estacado and his entire crime family. I very nearly stopped playing the game. They were all run-of-the-mill and BASIC ♥♥♥♥♥es. Once you discover that this is simply a delusional fantasy of a man at a sanatorium , things begin to become interesting. The attention to detail in this game is another aspect that I enjoyed thoroughly: The radio in the room. The phone conversations people have that give details about the story and make you wonder if you're insane. The really neat Lovecraft short film in the rec room. The paintings. My Ravioli's Too Spicy! (Pay attention to this, it's a hilarious overlap) The Darkness is a metaphor for mental illness and I'm pretty sure that this illness is hereditary as there are references to his father attempting to find a cure for the darkness for himself and his boy. In closing, the transition and overlap between real-life and fantasy is very well implemented, and in my opinion was the most interesting part of the game. The ending was sort of ridiculous, but all of the other positive aspects definitely made up for it.   8.5/10

The total amount of time it took me to play through the game is as you see. 5 whole hours.  Now normally I would be pretty irritated with a game only having 5 hours worth of gameplay. It's pretty absurd, even for a shooter with some RPG mechanics. However, I purchased this game for 80% off, so it was a steal on my end, and 5 hours for a game that was less than $10 (far less if I recall), isn't really all that bad of a deal.  On to the meat of things.  The game graphics are pretty good, nothing spectacular, but even after 8 years they still had their appeal. The game is extremely graphic for kill moves and blood/gore, so if you're a gorehound you shouldn't be surprised as a basic mechanic in the game is ripping out hearts and eating them.  The big thing for me in this was the gameplay though. It's fast and furious and never lets up. The tentacle controls are fluid as are the handling of the weapons in the game and both are easy to grasp and quick to master. The difficulty of the game isn't broken (which is always a plus) and even when you die you don't have to repeat massive chunks of the game over again (which is also a plus).   Story...well...okay so here's the thing. The story is kinda blah, not bad, just blah. Sure it has its moments, and anytime Jackie gets to sit in the dark smokey room and talk for a bit I'm all ears, but it's still blah, or rather, generic if you will. This game follows the aftermath of the first Darkness, of which I only played through the tutorial. I was sidetracked with other games at the time and just overlooked it, so it never got the playtime it deserved.  The story compared to the comics is pretty spot on. Power wise, probably not so much as the comic version is pretty much godlike, and while in this game you're no push-over, you're not a god either. But hey, that's where the fun comes in. There is enough progression using their power trees to allow you to be awesome with guns, awesome with the Darkness, or handy with both. Of course the game offers you the option to continue playing after the story is over using the 'newgame+' feature which will make you feel like the powerhouse everyone claims you to be should you go back and play this game sometime down the road.  The ending to the story was a bit of a let down, and somewhat silly, and featured some re-skinned models of baddies. But that's pretty much the whole game. No real enemy variety combat wise until you're 70% done with the game, and everything is just a re-skin of the same basic model. It's a shooter, so I don't expect much, but I do expect demons to be a little different from the mobsters in the game and not just a re-skin of the mobster and his gun. Give me some crazy flaming sword guys, or flying tentacle creatures or something!  I only recommend getting this game at it's discounted times, as the full version will leave you with a little bit of a disappointed feeling.

This game manages to slip its story on you while you're multilating anything and everything in a way that holds onto you until the end; Whichever ending you get will leave you wanting more. Compared to the first it's much more linear and plays more like an arcade shooter, but the first game's small open world often suffered from terrible pacing because of slow walk speed so the change is welcomed.  All this said against the previous game, but it isn't necessarily bad. It's a somber, noir style compared to the Darkness II's raw, bloody, cel-shaded multitasking gameplay. If you like this and want more the first is a safe buy, but not without its problems. I want part 3.

The combat has you wielding three different guns that you harvest off the dead or find and utilizing the Darkness as you see fit. The general weapon categories are pistols, smgs, rifles, and shotguns. I was a big fan of dual-wielding Desert Eagles. The Darkness on the other hand can pick up and throw various objects and people. You also have your dependable tentacle melee attacks that will slice people in half horizontally and vertically. Making your tentacles, guns, and powers all work together kept me interested in the game along with the revenge style story.  Unfortunately, the game has many problems. My problems weren't restricted to my experience either going off of what I read in the hub and in reviews. UPDATED REVIEW: My biggest problem, is that there is not enough content in the game: the campaign is short, the coop missions are too easy and the coop campaign is too short. So I'd say it doesn't worth the money - if there is a discount maybe (but looking back I definitely wouldn't give more than 5 Euros for it). However, an interesting game, could have been a very good one. The base idea is interesting. Good gamespeed (in the short campaign you won't feel bored), average story, but it has a certain style (which is not for everyone). Maybe I would recommended for those, who like unique shooter games (FPS), and would like to have a really short game. The story: i won't make spoiler, it's not bad (i've seen much worse), but a little simple. The evolution of the skills are well-made, which is absolutely a good point. There are not so many guns, but that's not a problem, because at least, they are really not the same (i mean, there are real differences between two guns, not just the look of them). There are 3 major negatives: 1. Graphic is bad. It is like a cartoon, but i think it wasn't a good choice. 2. Story is very short. I walk through the campaign in 1 day. 3. You are overpowered (mainly because of close combat - if you get close, you won). Even on highest difficulty, there aren't really difficult situations (maybe 1 or 2 during whole campaign). You can easily beat the coop missions alone.  I would say, that it's an average game, good for a weekend, but not for more, so in conclusion I don't recommend it.  If there will be a 3rd part, I would be interested in that, given that they change the graphic, and add much more story.

(Note: I didn't play the first The Darkness game nor do I have experience with The Darkness comic books)  At its best The Darkness II is a very stylish game. The comic book origins of this title really come out in a positive way in that regard. Sadly the gameplay does not live up to the presentation aspect of this title.  At the very best you can call The Darkness II an above average shooter. It does nothing special which might sound weird considering how you basically are a semi-god demon monster with tentacles coming out of you ready to rip enemies and the envinroment alike apart. It's just very basic under the shiny shell. You're not really encouraged to utilize your demonic skills and when you do it just doesn't feel very cool.   Naturally darkness is weak to light which brings us to a very frustrating gameplay mechanic. Remember how everyone loves getting hit by flashbangs in shooters? Me neither. The Darkness II manages to take this to another level. Light makes you incapable of using your demon skills which in practice means whatever plan you had with impaling an enemy with that spear-like object you can forget. The real pain starts when enemies start using light against you. This results in many chaotic moments where you just have no idea where to shoot to regain some level of control over the game. The blinding effect of light is way overdone and will make you feel frustrated. When you being the badass mob leader demon you are have to stop every time coming to a new area to snipe off lightbulbs with your pistol you know something is not done right. To top this off the game has a bug which frequently makes motion blur 'reverse'. What this means is that everytime the motion blur should be off it's on and vice versa. It's not enough to destroy the experience but it's annoying.  The story is The Darkness II's best part. It's not magnificient but it will keep you interested. Characters are solid with a few really standing out. That said I felt very unsatisfied with the ending. As a stand-alone product it doesn't really work.   After about 7 hours of singleplayer campaign you don't have much to do. You can hunt down relics (with some really interesting descriptions as a reward I have to say!) or try a harder difficulty level. The game also features the 'mandatory online element' where four of your friends take on separate missions from main story. With no real story I had absolutely no motivation in trying my hands at those the gameplay being mediocre. If you want a multiplayer co-op shooter I'm sure you can think of better ways of spending your time and money.  After all the complaining you might think I hate the game but this is not the case at all. Beyond the presentation it's just not anything special. Mediocrity is not a crime and I'd say The Darkness is definitely worth it if you can find a great deal. At anywhere close to the full price I wouldn't consider it.

This game it is not a complete disaster, even though I do not personally recommend it. It's not recommended only if you've played the original The Darkness on console.   In any case: this is what I call a missed opportunity. The Darkness II tries to continue the adventures of the unlucky Jackie Estacado, tormented by the death of his girlfriend Jenny, with The Darkness itself to spice the things up.  As written in the comic books, Jackie is the carrier of an antique evil force that humans passed on from generations to generations constantly fighting its counterpart, the Light. In this chapter we'll se a mysterious cult who is pursuing him to steal his mystical power. Unfortunately, the plot is the weakest part of the experience, and it is a shame, because the gameplay is satisfying. Being the Darkness is a good experience, you can feel like an overpowered creature who can slaughter and kill everything it breathes. Although there are few powers that you can play with, they're fun to use. Also the environment interaction is pretty good, in fact you can take various object with your demonic limb and throw them to your foes with enjoyable and squishy results. The game encourages you to do so in many different ways, as you can earn Dark Essence (XP) to unlock powers and abilities. The gunplay instead, it's sufficient: no recoil, the weapons sound and feel all over the same. The only difference you can tell about them is the fire ratio. It suffers from the modern FPS syndrome: high difficulty = enemies have lots of health points, so going further with the game usually is just trying and failing with a poor challenge. At least there's not regenerating health because you have to eat hearts from dead enemies in order to replenish it. There is also a limited multiplayer coop mode with 4 characters to choose from with different skills and abilities, but it adds nothing to the experience, it's just another excuse to shoot everything. Maybe this mode was built in order to extend the game length, because the singleplayer campaign is very short (about 6 hours).   Do yourself a favor: if you own a PS3 or Xbox360 go and grab a copy of the first game. You won't be disappointed.
